Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Voting, King said in an interview, gives 'a little bit of your strength back and a little bit of your voice back. Being able to vote, being able to have a say in what happens in your society, in your state, is extremely important.'
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: outreach specialist with the Nebraska AIDS Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: came off probation in August after serving time for drug and theft convictions; fought addiction for years and spent five years in prison after being convicted of possessing the party drug Ecstasy and theft by deception, ending probation last August; works in the HIV/AIDS field and volunteers at various organizations

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: 'Restoring voting rights really is an issue where we've seen bipartisan momentum,' said Patrick Berry

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: 'You're civically dead and you can't vote for the people who are levying those taxes,' he said.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: 'I do think that hopefully the waiting period reinforces the fact that voting is something very special, and hopefully that will be part of the things that an individual would consider if they're tempted to break the law again,' she said.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: 'I felt so hopeless and helpless not being able to have my voice heard in this last election,' King said. 'There are a lot of things that were on the ballot here in Nebraska that hit home with a lot of things that I advocate for.'

Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Since her 2018 release, she has obtained graduate degrees and served in a variety of roles; set up her own nonprofit and is executive director of Q.U.E.E.N.S Butterfly House, a safe house for women trying to reenter society

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: 'You can't harm society by voting,' he said. 'You can only help it.'
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: was paroled in 2015 after serving more than four years on assault and other charges; owns his own business, a physical rehabilitation and athletic coaching center; has regained voting rights and cast ballots for Republican candidates in his first elections

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: In Nebraska, nearly 18,000 people are unable to vote because of felony convictions, said the Sentencing Project's director of advocacy, Nicole Porter. That includes 7,072 who fall under the two-year wait requirement and are currently unable to cast a ballot. The rest have not completed their full sentences.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: studies the issue and advocates for restoration of voting rights for former felons
